newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakh-U.S. firm to build 150-megawatt power plant.
newsitem.headline: Kazakh-U.S. firm to build 150-megawatt power plant.

text.p: A joint U.S.-Kazakh venture called Erem Aktobe is to build a gas-turbine power plant with annual capacity of 150 megawatts at an estimated cost of $80 million in Kazakhstan's north-western Aktyubinsk region, an official from the Kazakh presidential news service told Reuters.

He said President Nursultan Nazarbayev flew to the regional centre on Wednesday to take part in a ceremony at the start of construction of the plant which is to run on gas from the nearby Zhanazhol oil and gas field.
The project is being financed by the U.S. partner in the joint venture, New Century Holdings, which will get a 75 percent stake in the power plant.
New Century is a U.S. investment fund active in the Baltics and Eastern Europe and already holds stakes in a number of Russian telecoms and energy firms.
It will finance one half of Erem Aktobe's costs itself and has pledged to attract the rest in loans from a number of U.S. banks for terms of up to seven years, the news service said.
The Kazakh side in the venture, represented by companies TOO Invest Region and TOO Tsentralnaya AZS, will get a combined 25 percent stake in the plant.

"The chance to build the plant was initially offered by the Kazakh government to Swiss-Swedish concern ABB AG but, unfortunately, it did not provide financing possibilities," Energy and Natural Resources Minister Viktor Khrapunov told Reuters on Tuesday.
The equipment -- four energy blocks of around 40 megawatts each -- will be made by General Electric Co of the U.S.
The first block will start up by the end of this year, the news service said.
At around the same time, the first part of the neighbouring Zhanazhol gas-turbine power plant with annual capacity of 48 megawatts will be launched.
This station is being built with the help of the local Aktyubinskneft oil company. The cost of the project is $11.1 million.

Kazakh officials have said previously that building gas-turbine energy plants in Aktyubinsk was a priority because of the lack of electricity in the region and its isolation from other energy systems in Kazakhstan.
"We need to achieve energy independence in the republic's north-west, which is still dependent on Russian electricity producers," Khrapunov said.
